page.title: 17PUBLIC HOUSES IN SADDLEWORTH
page.content: The Cross Keys Inn, originally called the 'Gravemakers' is near Saddleworth Church & accessible by a field path, said to be the former packhorse road. It was built in 1745 by the Bottomley family, & owned by the Buckley's for over 100 years. An upper room was used for Hunt Suppers in the 1920's & 30's, & black pudding was traditionally served. Hare-hunting was the main sport of the area & Saddleworth had its own pack of hounds, which had no permanent quarters but were farmed out to any members of the hunt. The tap room at the Inn still has white-topped tables, flagged floor & old-fashioned fireplace. It is the present base for the Oldham Mountain Rescue team, the Saddleworth Outdoor Pursuits Assoc. & Saddleworth Morris Men. The Church Inn (formerly New Inn) is nearby & has an old fireplace & handbells of interest.
